claim: Our modified genetic algorithm achieves 15% improvement on TSP instances compared to standard GA
context: Tested on 25 TSPLIB instances ranging from 50 to 200 cities
evidence: Average tour length reduction of 15.3% across all instances
Statistical significance p < 0.01 via paired t-test
Consistent improvement across different city counts
assumptions: Same population size and generation count for both algorithms
predictions: Improvement will hold on untested TSPLIB instances
Improvement may not generalize to non-TSP routing problems
Performance depends on population diversity maintenance

claim: Deep learning model achieves state-of-the-art performance on MNIST dataset
context: CNN architecture with 5 layers, trained on full MNIST training set

claim: Proposed sorting algorithm has O(n log n) worst-case complexity
context: Comparison-based sorting using modified quicksort with median-of-medians pivot
assumptions: Input is an array of comparable elements
Random access to array elements is O(1)
predictions: Will maintain O(n log n) on adversarial inputs
Constants are higher than standard quicksort

claim: New approximation algorithm achieves 1.5-approximation for vertex cover
context: Polynomial-time greedy algorithm with local search refinement
assumptions: Approximation ratio measured against optimal solution
